reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s discussion of “reflection” in §2.3.1 and the idea that more cognitive power might yield better moral views/convergence. But this is only weakly central to the essay’s overall position, because the authors explicitly argue that superintelligent reflection does not imply convergence and use §2.3.1 largely to caution against optimism (they already emphasize advisor-selection, motivated cognition, and refusal to defer to reflective selves). As a result, even if the critique were right about human reasoning being mostly post-hoc rationalization, it would not significantly undermine the essay—much of it is already compatible with the authors’ stance. Strength is low because it partly attacks a strawman (“mistakenly predict convergence”) and provides no concrete engagement with the essay’s actual anti-convergence arguments (metaethics, motivational issues, threats/trade). Correctness is mixed: motivated reasoning/signaling is a well-supported theme in cognitive science, but the critique overgeneralizes (from humans to ‘likely intelligent agents’), overstates (“largely”/“naive Cartesian”), and asserts an author prediction that the text does not make. The critique is clear and focused with little dead weight.
title: Reflection may entrench bias through sophisticated rationalization rather than reveal truth
